The fact that work and reports have been filed, violations noted, and yet no penalties have been assessed is utterly perplexing. It makes me wonder why any effort is being made in the first place if the findings are not acted upon. This type of negligence would not be tolerated in any other field, therefore our government's inaction is simply ludicrous. It is clear that we need more individuals like Erin Brockovich who are willing to impose steep fines upon those responsible for such incidents. As a member of society, I am deeply concerned about the impact this negligence can have on the health and safety of our children.

The news of children dying due to their parents' carelessness with drugs makes me extremely angry. It's outrageous to think that parents would be so irresponsible as to leave dangerous substances within reach of their children. Such negligent behavior shows a lack of responsibility and disregard for the safety and wellbeing of their children. It's necessary for parents to ensure that dangerous drugs are always kept out of reach of children and to be vigilant in checking for any hazards that may harm them. The lives of innocent children should never be put at risk due to the carelessness of others.

In this day and age, it's disheartening to see that we haven't made much progress when it comes to gender equality. It's alarming to know that the USA is ranked 45th, trailing behind African countries. It seems that for the past century, politics and the government have taken precedence over ensuring fairness and equality for all genders. Personally, I have experienced discrimination in my career, where my male colleague, who had an identical job as me, was paid 40% more than I was. Sadly, speaking out about it could lead to losing my job, as almost every state has at-will employment laws. The injustice and inequality that still exists in this day and age evoke emotions of anger, disgust, and sadness.

After reading this article, I must express my discontent and disagreement with the perspective presented. The article suggests that Trump is solely responsible for any harm done to Israel, which is a false accusation. In fact, Trump has been a major ally to Israel, unlike his predecessor Obama who failed to support Israel and even allied with its mortal enemy, Iran. It's unfair to place the blame on Trump for any rise in anti-Semitic sentiment. Rather, he is a symptom of the wider cultural changes that have been long overdue. The pushback by whites and males in 2016 was due to a sense of aggression from the constantly shoved in faces of the LGBTQ+ community, minorities, and women. The issues we face are much deeper than Trump's presidency, and we need to address them as such. Welcome to the resistance.

Upon reading about the ethnic and religious conflicts, displacement of people, government crackdowns, and violent extremist actions, I find myself feeling emotionally drained and disconnected from these critical issues. Although I understand that these problems are internal affairs, I am of the opinion that every country has the right to protect its people and maintain its sovereignty against any perceived threats. However, the UN's self-righteous interference in matters that do not concern them has left me feeling angry. I am frustrated by their criticisms of governments for not doing enough or for being too strict with perceived threats, without considering the bigger picture. It is bewildering how the UN can turn a blind eye to a government's right to protect its people against real and existential threats while prioritizing the sheltering of refugees on superficial moral grounds. The UN's lack of action amounts to nothing more than a do-nothing, pompous display of self-righteousness.

The airstrikes have caused me great concern, as they have led to the loss of numerous innocent lives. It's heartbreaking to see not only combatants but also children and babies being killed. This situation calls for immediate action to prevent the senseless loss of lives. My heart fills with anger and disgust as I think about the affected individuals and families who are suffering. I firmly believe that measures must be taken to bring an end to this tragedy.

I fully support the ban, as witnessing people smoke near playgrounds fills me with disgust. On one occasion, I even felt compelled to leave due to the overwhelming amount of smoke being exhaled, and I didn't want my children to inhale it. It's just preposterous to suggest that running through a cloud of smoke wouldn't be harmful for a child. Regarding the argument that it sets a bad example, I believe that while it may be true, we cannot simply erase every negative influence from society in an attempt to shield people from life's realities. It is ultimately the responsibility of parents to educate their children on what is right and wrong.

As I read the news article about tourists hurting the polar bears, I feel a mix of anger and sadness in my heart. It's utterly dreadful that humans can intentionally cause harm to innocent animals and still have a good night's sleep. In my opinion, people should not even be in close proximity to polar bears. These creatures deserve to be left alone in their natural habitat.

The airstrikes are a cause of grave concern, as numerous innocent lives are being lost. It's not just the combatants who are perishing, but children and babies as well. This situation demands urgent attention and action needs to be taken to prevent the senseless loss of lives. The plight of the affected individuals and families fills me with anger and disgust, and I strongly believe that steps must be taken to put an end to this tragedy.

In light of recent news articles highlighting harm to individuals or groups, I was left feeling disgusted by the actions of men in powerful positions. It's alarming that they choose to use their status as a means to attack women, thinking they can get away with it without consequence. Unfortunately, such stories are becoming increasingly common, underscoring the need to educate people earlier on about sexual assault and appropriate behaviour. Moreover, we require programs and resources that empower women to speak out against perpetrators, ensuring they are held accountable so that such behavior does not recur. The affected women were trapped by their abusers' positions of power, and I can only imagine the trauma they must have experienced. No one deserves to suffer through something like this and no one should have to endure it alone. It is crucial that we never sweep such incidents under the rug or place the blame on the victims.

The fact that the ride was not shut down and properly investigated really infuriates me. My heart breaks for the individuals who lost their lives as a result of this negligence. The thought of the daughter having to witness her mother's tragic death on a ride that was meant to be a source of joy is absolutely heartbreaking. I cannot fathom how she will be able to recover from such a traumatic experience. The entire situation is truly saddening.

I am deeply frustrated by the fact that our oceans are being polluted, and this problem is resulting in the harm of innocent animals. The notion that something as simple as plastic floating in the ocean can cause harm to sea birds is both absurd and understandable. It is maddening that humans are constantly causing harm to things that should have never been tampered with in the first place. The damage that our trash is causing fills me with anger and sadness.

After reading the news about the ongoing violence in Yemen, I feel completely drained emotionally. The majority of the victims are innocent civilians and it's disgusting to think that the violence is supported by the US-backed Saudi aggression. I strongly believe that the US should stay out of international conflicts and avoid meddling in the affairs of other nations. Even if there is a tenuous peace, the governments that are installed by US interests are bound to fail sooner or later. It's heartbreaking to see the suffering caused by this vicious cycle of violence and interference.

After reading the news article about tourists harming polar bears, a feeling of overwhelming sadness and anger has consumed me. It is appalling that individuals can knowingly cause harm to these innocent creatures while still being able to sleep soundly at night. Personally, I believe that polar bears should not be exposed to humans at close range. They should be allowed to live undisturbed in their natural environment.

I feel outraged upon learning that such events are still taking place in 2019. The mere fact that one country must assist another with troops highlights that we are not as advanced as some people believe. Kenya recently deported an official, fully aware that the individual faced the high probability of death upon returning to Sudan. This action is callous and reprehensible, and Kenya should feel deep shame for their involvement in this tragedy.

The story is a heart-wrenching one, but unfortunately not uncommon in third-world countries where people sell fuel at the roadside. The enormity of the world is beyond comprehension and incidents of death, suffering, and tragedy happen all too often. While I understand that there are grieving families, to me, these people are like characters from a storybook, unknown until their death. It's difficult for me to feel any strong emotions towards them. Although this event happened, it doesn't seem real or important to me. Despite what society says, I don't believe that knowing about these deaths makes the world a better place.

The idea that wars can be fought without civilian casualties baffles me. War is an inherently grim and messy business; there's no 'polite' way to wage it. If you want to win, you have to fight dirty and fight hard. World War 2 wasn't won by 'playing nice'  we had to resort to nuclear weapons and level Germany. Civilians are an inevitable part of the equation. In Yemen, the decision to allow rebel groups supported by Iran to take over has put innocent citizens in danger and resulted in threats to Saudi Arabia. The notion that the Saudis should prioritize protecting the Yemeni over their own citizens is ridiculous. They should fight with everything they have, regardless of the consequences. Winning the war is what matters, not sparing people's feelings. This kind of naive thinking is dangerous.

Upon reading the article, my initial response was one of rage. The sheer thought that a father could willfully end the lives of his own flesh and blood is inconceivable. It is a repulsive and heinous act, and the man behind it is clearly unhinged. I contemplate whether the perpetrator might be afflicted with a severe mental illness or under the influence of drugs.

After reading about the killing of elephants for ivory, I am filled with a burning anger. It is appalling to think that humans could be so callous towards another species, especially one as majestic and intelligent as elephants. I fear that if we do not take the threat of their possible extinction seriously, we will soon lose these magnificent creatures forever. The poachers are certainly a major part of the problem, but we cannot overlook the responsibility of those who are buying the ivory. To make a significant impact, we must address both the supply and the demand of ivory. I strongly believe that only by cracking down on both sides of this issue can we hope to see real change and save the elephants from this senseless slaughter.

The news of American troop deaths always makes me angry and saddened. It's heart-wrenching to think about the Captain and First Sergeant who lost their lives - they were experienced and held high-ranking positions. As for the civilians who suffered the same fate, I can't help but feel less sympathetic towards them. My strong belief is that when a war is being fought, it should be fought hard, and an expected collateral damage cannot be avoided. Past wars, such as WWII, were won by leveling Germany and nuking Japan. It's impossible to isolate and only kill the bad guys. Although it may seem harsh, killing civilians is sometimes necessary to end wars. Just targeting the insurgents or guerillas doesn't help in achieving a win in the war - it only prolongs the suffering and causes more casualties.

Although I acknowledge that the women broke a leash law, I strongly believe that the punishment they received was not proportional to the crime. The man's actions, of shooting a dog for merely running up to him, appear to be an overreaction and unacceptable. He should face criminal charges for his irresponsible use of firearms. As much as I support conceal and carry laws, they should not be an excuse for someone to behave recklessly and cause harm. This person must be held accountable for his actions and face the consequences of his wrongdoing.

Hey Nora, did you get a chance to read about the handler who left his police dog, Lina, in a hot car in Arkansas? Lina was an important member of the sheriff's office and achieved a great deal in drug investigations over three years. The handler has been put on paid administrative leave while authorities investigate this shocking incident. I can't believe someone could leave a police dog in a high-temperature car for 38 hours without realizing, it's beyond comprehension. The lack of regard for the safety and well-being of animals and humans is outrageous. Unfortunately, this is not the only case - this year alone, including children, we have lost 82 innocent lives. It's unacceptable and deeply disturbs me, filling me with anger. I refuse to accept any reasons put forward for such recklessness.

The content of these news articles is extremely disconcerting. It's difficult to comprehend how anyone could demonstrate empathy or pause when confronted with the threat of militant Islam. Such individuals are nothing more than violent savages who deserve no quarter or mercy. It's disgraceful that we withdrew from the region in a cowardly manner. Furthermore, it's hard to ignore the fact that the people of this region are partially to blame for their predicament. They're complicit in allowing this toxic ideology to fester, and they're now paying the price. Although one might argue that it's a result of U.S. interference, the truth is that it's been around for centuries. Other nations have fought against their foes, both internal and external, without being passive. Yet, the Arabs and Persians seem to be content with being impotent under their overlords.

After reading about the ethnic and religious conflicts, displaced people, governments cracking down, and terrorist groups, I find myself drained and disconnected from the issue. Although I understand that these are internal affairs, I agree that each country has the right to protect its sovereignty and people against perceived threats. However, I feel anger towards the UN's self-righteous interference in matters that are not their concern. Their criticisms of governments for not doing enough or for cracking down too hard on perceived threats do not take into account the bigger picture. How can they ignore a government's right to defend itself against existential threats and prioritize the sheltering of refugees under superficial moral grounds? The UN's lack of action is nothing more than a pompous display of do-nothing self-righteousness.

The news of this incident is truly heartbreaking and devastating. It is beyond selfish to take the lives of innocent people, especially one's own family. If this man was struggling with a breakdown after losing his wife, he should have sought professional help to work through his issues with her. His children, who were innocent, were denied their right to life. This act was not only ungodly, but also cowardly, and leaves me at a loss for words. The emotions that come to mind are anger towards the perpetrator and immense sorrow for the wife and kids.

After reading the article about how veterans are being neglected, I feel more than just sad  I am filled with anger. It's a disgraceful reality that we are not doing enough to honor and take care of our veterans who have sacrificed so much for our country. I am heartened, however, to see a growing number of people speaking out about PTSD and other issues affecting our vets. It's time for us to stop ignoring these problems and start taking action. We must commit to working individually with each veteran, ensuring they receive the care and support they need and deserve.

Lina was an important part of the sheriff's office and had contributed immensely to drug investigations over the past three years. Unfortunately, this is not an isolated incident and this year alone we have already lost 82 innocent lives, including children. This deeply troubles me and fills me with anger. Regardless of any reasons put forward for such recklessness, I refuse to accept them as valid excuses.

The news of troops being killed in Afghanistan fills me with anger because we shouldn't have been there in the first place. The fact that we continue to remain in the country speaks volumes about our nation. We must come to terms with the fact that we have no legitimate reason to be there any longer and it's time to withdraw. It baffles me why we are still trying to play the role of the world police when it serves no meaningful purpose in the end.

After reading about the harm caused to a person or group, I realize that this issue is rampant in the region. It's disheartening to see that the economy is given more importance than anything else, especially when the population is so high. It's distressing to see that environmentalism is a losing battle when we have countries like Indonesia burning their forests to produce palm oil. It's frustrating that the U.S. and other civilized countries try to do everything in their power to save the environment but it seems to be a futile effort. It's appalling that we are considered barbarians in the world even though most of the world is one step above apes, consisting of heathens. Reagan made a correct observation when he asked Nixon whether we leave our fate to people who don't even wear shoes. It's absurd to think that we treat these people as equals. The anger and disgust I feel after reading this article is unfathomable.

It is heartbreaking to read about the atrocities committed against innocent animals. The fact that humans continue to capture and enslave these creatures and deprive them of proper care is truly despicable. It is a sad and wicked situation that makes one wonder why humans have to be so cruel. We must learn to leave things as they are if we are incapable of providing these animals with the care that nature intended for them. It is not right to continue spoiling everything that nature has given us in the name of domination. We need to recognize that our actions have consequences and make an effort to do better.
